cluster.cot:
Based on the user's query about major serum proteins in the biomolecular corona of LNPs and their impact on cellular targeting and tissue distribution, I need to organize the provided quote into meaningful dimensions.

The query has two main components:
1. Identifying which major serum proteins are incorporated into the biomolecular corona of LNPs
2. Understanding how these proteins modulate cellular targeting and tissue distribution

Looking at the quote provided, it contains information about protein corona composition on nanoparticles (specifically mentioned as cNPs) but doesn't directly address the cellular targeting and tissue distribution aspects. The quote also doesn't specifically mention LNPs (lipid nanoparticles) but discusses nanoparticles more generally.

I'll organize the information into the following dimensions:

1. "Introduction to Protein Corona" - This will be a synthesis paragraph providing background on what a protein corona is and why it matters for nanoparticles, particularly LNPs. This section doesn't have supporting quotes but is necessary for context.

2. "Major Serum Proteins in Nanoparticle Corona" - This will be a synthesis paragraph discussing which major serum proteins are found in the corona of nanoparticles. The quote provides information about apolipoproteins, complement proteins, coagulation proteins, and notably mentions that albumin and macroglobulin are present in smaller proportions than their plasma abundance would suggest. This is directly addressing the first part of the query.

3. "Impact on Cellular Targeting and Tissue Distribution" - This would be a synthesis paragraph addressing the second part of the query, but the quote doesn't provide information on this aspect. I'll include this dimension with an empty quotes list to acknowledge this important aspect of the query that isn't addressed in the provided material.

For the single quote provided, I'll assign it to the "Major Serum Proteins in Nanoparticle Corona" dimension, as it directly discusses the protein composition of nanoparticle coronas.

sections.title: Introduction to Protein Corona
sections.tldr: When lipid nanoparticles (LNPs) enter biological fluids, they rapidly acquire a layer of proteins called the "protein corona" that significantly alters their biological identity. This corona formation is a dynamic process that influences how the nanoparticles interact with cells and tissues, ultimately determining their therapeutic efficacy and biodistribution. (LLM Memory)
sections.text:
The protein corona forms when nanoparticles, including lipid nanoparticles (LNPs), come into contact with biological fluids such as blood. Within seconds of exposure, plasma proteins adsorb onto the surface of the nanoparticles, creating a dynamic layer that can substantially change the nanoparticle's size, surface charge, and biological properties. This protein coating effectively creates a new biological identity for the nanoparticle that cells "see" rather than the original engineered surface. <Model name="Anthropic" version="claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219">

The corona formation occurs in two distinct phases: first, a "hard" corona of proteins with high affinity for the nanoparticle surface forms, creating a relatively stable layer; second, a more loosely bound "soft" corona develops through protein-protein interactions. The composition of this corona is not static but evolves over time as proteins with higher affinity displace those with lower affinity, a phenomenon known as the Vroman effect. <Model name="Anthropic" version="claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219">

The specific proteins that adsorb to nanoparticles depend on multiple factors including the nanoparticle's physicochemical properties (size, shape, surface charge, hydrophobicity), the biological environment (plasma, interstitial fluid, etc.), and exposure time. For LNPs specifically used in drug and vaccine delivery, understanding this corona formation is crucial as it directly influences cellular uptake mechanisms, biodistribution patterns, immune recognition, and ultimately therapeutic efficacy. <Model name="Anthropic" version="claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219">

sections.title: Major Serum Proteins in Nanoparticle Corona
sections.tldr: The protein corona of lipid nanoparticles is dominated by apolipoproteins, complement proteins, and coagulation factors, while surprisingly containing relatively small amounts of serum albumin despite its abundance in plasma. The specific composition varies based on nanoparticle properties, with proteins in the 30-60 kDa range and those bearing negative charges being significantly enriched. (3 sources)
sections.text:
The protein corona that forms around nanoparticles demonstrates selective enrichment of specific serum proteins rather than simply reflecting their relative abundance in plasma. Proteomic analysis has revealed that proteins with molecular weights between 30-60 kDa constitute the majority of adsorbed proteins on nanoparticle surfaces. Additionally, proteins with a net negative charge (pI < 7) are significantly enriched in nanoparticle coronas regardless of the type of nanoparticle examined. <Paper corpusId="243474993" paperTitle="(Liu et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>

Apolipoproteins consistently emerge as the most abundant plasma proteins in the corona of various nanoparticles, suggesting they play a crucial role in mediating nanoparticle-cell interactions. Complement proteins are also found in high abundance in many nanoparticle coronas, particularly certain formulations, which may have implications for immune system recognition. Depending on the specific nanoparticle composition, other protein classes like coagulation factors, tissue leakage proteins, and acute phase proteins may be differentially represented in the corona. <Paper corpusId="243474993" paperTitle="(Liu et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>

One of the most striking observations is that serum albumin, despite being the most abundant protein in plasma (>50%), typically represents only a minor component (10% or less) of the nanoparticle corona. Similarly, macroglobulins, which are the second most abundant plasma proteins, often appear only as the 7th to 11th most abundant proteins in nanoparticle coronas. <Paper corpusId="243474993" paperTitle="(Liu et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper> This selective protein adsorption demonstrates that corona formation is not simply driven by protein concentration in plasma but involves complex interactions between nanoparticle surfaces and specific protein characteristics. <Paper corpusId="20368854" paperTitle="(Tenzer et al., 2011)" isShortName></Paper>

The composition of this protein corona is not merely a function of electrostatic interactions, as protein decoration of negatively charged particles does not directly correlate with protein size or charge. Even minor differences in nanoparticle size (as small as 10 nm) can significantly alter the corona composition, affecting the binding of biologically relevant proteins that influence cellular interactions. <Paper corpusId="20368854" paperTitle="(Tenzer et al., 2011)" isShortName></Paper> Furthermore, the hydrophobicity and arrangement of chemical motifs on nanoparticle surfaces play critical roles in determining which proteins preferentially adsorb to form the corona. <Paper corpusId="206700067" paperTitle="(Saha et al., 2016)" isShortName></Paper>

snippets: Proteomic analysis showed that the plasma proteins with a 30-60 kDa molecular weight constituted the majority of the adsorbed proteins (Fig. 6A) and the proteins bearing a net negative charge (pI < 7) were significantly enriched in all cNPs' protein corona, irrespective of the type of nanoparticle (Fig. 6B)

Apolipoprotein was the most abundant plasma proteins in the protein corona of all the tested cNPs, whereas the complement proteins were found in high abundance in the protein corona of cNP1 and cNP3. The protein corona of cNP1 showed a high abundance of coagulation proteins and tissue leakage proteins, while the corona of cNP3 showed a high abundance of acute phase proteins (Fig. 6C)

Notably, the coronas of all four cNPs contained relatively small amounts of serum albumin (10% or less) which is the most abundant protein in plasma (more than 50%) (Saha et al., 2016)(Tenzer et al., 2011)
Macroglobulin, the second most abundant plasma protein [35], was only the 7-11th most abundant protein detectable on the corona of cNP1-cNP3.

paper.title: The protein corona modulates the inflammation inhibition by cationic nanoparticles via cell-free DNA scavenging

snippets: In biological fluids, proteins associate with nanoparticles, leading to a protein "corona" defining the biological identity of the particle. However, a comprehensive knowledge of particle-guided protein fingerprints and their dependence on nanomaterial properties is incomplete. We studied the long-lived ("hard") blood plasma derived corona on monodispersed amorphous silica nanoparticles differing in size (20, 30, and 100 nm). Employing label-free liquid chromatography mass spectrometry, one- and two-dimensional gel electrophoresis, and immunoblotting the composition of the protein corona was analyzed not only qualitatively but also quantitatively. Detected proteins were bioinformatically classified according to their physicochemical and biological properties. Binding of the 125 identified proteins did not simply reflect their relative abundance in the plasma but revealed an enrichment of specific lipoproteins as well as proteins involved in coagulation and the complement pathway. In contrast, immunoglobulins and acute phase response proteins displayed a lower affinity for the particles. Protein decoration of the negatively charged particles did not correlate with protein size or charge, demonstrating that electrostatic effects alone are not the major driving force regulating the nanoparticle-protein interaction. Remarkably, even differences in particle size of only 10 nm significantly determined the nanoparticle corona, although no clear correlation with particle surface volume, protein size, or charge was evident. Particle size quantitatively influenced the particle's decoration with 37% of all identified proteins, including (patho)biologically relevant candidates. We demonstrate the complexity of the plasma corona and its still unresolved physicochemical regulation, which need to be considered in nanobioscience in the future.

paper.title: Nanoparticle size is a critical physicochemical determinant of the human blood plasma corona: a comprehensive quantitative proteomic analysis.

snippets: Using a family of cationic gold nanoparticles (NPs) with similar size and charge, we demonstrate that proper surface engineering can control the nature and identity of protein corona in physiological serum conditions. The protein coronas were highly dependent on the hydrophobicity and arrangement of chemical motifs on NP surface. The NPs were uptaken in macrophages in a corona-dependent manner, predominantly through recognition of specific complement proteins in the NP corona. Taken together, this study shows that surface functionality can be used to tune the protein corona formed on NP surface, dictating the interaction of NPs with macrophages.

paper.title: Regulation of Macrophage Recognition through the Interplay of Nanoparticle Surface Functionality and Protein Corona.

sections.title: Impact on Cellular Targeting and Tissue Distribution
sections.tldr: The protein corona dramatically alters how lipid nanoparticles interact with cells by changing receptor recognition, cellular uptake pathways, and immune system interactions. Specific proteins like apolipoproteins can enhance delivery to certain tissues (especially the liver), while complement proteins may trigger clearance, making corona composition a critical determinant of therapeutic efficacy. (LLM Memory)
sections.text:
The protein corona fundamentally transforms the biological identity of lipid nanoparticles (LNPs), directly influencing their cellular interactions and tissue distribution patterns. When specific proteins adsorb to the nanoparticle surface, they can either facilitate or hinder cellular uptake by providing recognition motifs for cell surface receptors. Particularly, apolipoproteins (especially ApoE) play a crucial role in LNP delivery to the liver by mediating interactions with low-density lipoprotein receptors (LDLR) that are highly expressed on hepatocytes. This explains why many LNP formulations show preferential liver accumulation, regardless of their original design intentions. <Model name="Anthropic" version="claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219">

The presence of different immunoglobulins and complement proteins in the corona can trigger recognition by immune cells through Fc and complement receptors, leading to rapid clearance by the mononuclear phagocyte system (MPS). This phenomenon, known as opsonization, significantly reduces circulation time and can prevent nanoparticles from reaching their intended targets. Conversely, the adsorption of specific proteins like clusterin (apolipoprotein J) or albumin may create a "stealth" effect that reduces immune recognition and extends circulation time. <Model name="Anthropic" version="claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219">

Coagulation factors in the corona can influence both blood compatibility and tissue targeting. When present in the corona, proteins like fibrinogen may trigger platelet activation and promote interactions with endothelial cells, potentially altering vascular permeability and tissue accumulation patterns. The presence of vitronectin and fibronectin can mediate binding to integrin receptors, affecting cellular uptake mechanisms across various tissue types. <Model name="Anthropic" version="claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219">

The corona composition also determines the specific endocytic pathway by which nanoparticles enter cells. Coronas rich in certain apolipoproteins tend to promote clathrin-mediated endocytosis, while those with abundant dysopsonins might favor caveolae-mediated uptake. These distinct entry mechanisms directly affect intracellular trafficking and ultimately determine whether the nanoparticle's cargo successfully reaches its intracellular target or becomes degraded in lysosomes. <Model name="Anthropic" version="claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219">

Importantly, the protein corona composition evolves as nanoparticles move between biological compartments, creating a "biological history" effect. Initial protein adsorption in blood may direct nanoparticles to specific tissues, but upon extravasation, the corona can undergo significant remodeling as it encounters interstitial fluid with different protein compositions. This dynamic evolution means that nanoparticle-cell interactions continue to change throughout their journey in the body, complicating efforts to predict and control their ultimate fate. <Model name="Anthropic" version="claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219">

Understanding and controlling protein corona formation has emerged as a critical consideration in LNP design. Strategies such as PEGylation, incorporation of specific targeting ligands that remain accessible despite corona formation, or pre-coating nanoparticles with desired proteins are being explored to overcome the biological barriers imposed by uncontrolled corona formation and to achieve more precise cellular targeting and tissue distribution profiles. <Model name="Anthropic" version="claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219">
